longdesc.p: The jQuery UI Draggable plugin makes selected elements draggable by mouse.

Draggable elements gets a class of ui-draggable. During drag the element also gets a class of ui-draggable-dragging. If you want not just drag, but drag-and-drop, see the jQuery UI Droppable plugin, which provides a drop target for draggables.
All callbacks (start, stop, drag) receive two arguments: The original browser event and a prepared ui object, view below for a documentation of this object (if you name your second argument 'ui'):

ul.li: ui.helper - the jQuery object representing the helper that's being dragged
ui.position - current position of the helper as { top, left } object, relative to the offset element
ui.offset - current absolute position of the helper as { top, left } object, relative to page

longdesc.p: To manipulate the position of a draggable during drag, you can either [http://jsbin.com/etako/edit use a wrapper as the draggable helper] and position the wrapped element with absolute positioning, or you can correct internal values like so: $(this).data('draggable').offset.click.top -= x.

option.name: addClasses
option.desc: If set to false, will prevent the ui-draggable class from being added. This may be desired as a performance optimization when calling .draggable() init on many hundreds of elements.

option.name: appendTo
option.desc: The element passed to or selected by the appendTo option will be used as the draggable helper's container during dragging. By default, the helper is appended to the same container as the draggable.

option.name: axis
option.desc: Constrains dragging to either the horizontal (x) or vertical (y) axis. Possible values: 'x', 'y'.

option.name: cancel
option.desc: Prevents dragging from starting on specified elements.

option.name: connectToSortable
option.desc:
Allows the draggable to be dropped onto the specified sortables. If this option is used (helper must be set to 'clone' in order to work flawlessly), a draggable can be dropped onto a sortable list and then becomes part of it.
Note: Specifying this option as an array of selectors has been removed.

option.name: containment
option.desc: Constrains dragging to within the bounds of the specified element or region. Possible string values: 'parent', 'document', 'window', [x1, y1, x2, y2].

option.name: cursor
option.desc: The css cursor during the drag operation.

option.name: cursorAt
option.desc: Sets the offset of the dragging helper relative to the mouse cursor. Coordinates can be given as a hash using a combination of one or two keys: { top, left, right, bottom }.

option.name: delay
option.desc: Time in milliseconds after mousedown until dragging should start. This option can be used to prevent unwanted drags when clicking on an element.

option.name: disabled
option.desc: Disables the draggable if set to true.

option.name: distance
option.desc: Distance in pixels after mousedown the mouse must move before dragging should start. This option can be used to prevent unwanted drags when clicking on an element.

option.name: grid
option.desc: Snaps the dragging helper to a grid, every x and y pixels. Array values: [x, y]

option.name: handle
option.desc: If specified, restricts drag start click to the specified element(s).

option.name: helper
option.desc: Allows for a helper element to be used for dragging display. Possible values: 'original', 'clone', Function. If a function is specified, it must return a DOMElement.

option.name: iframeFix
option.desc: Prevent iframes from capturing the mousemove events during a drag. Useful in combination with cursorAt, or in any case, if the mouse cursor is not over the helper. If set to true, transparent overlays will be placed over all iframes on the page. If a selector is supplied, the matched iframes will have an overlay placed over them.

option.name: opacity
option.desc: Opacity for the helper while being dragged.

option.name: refreshPositions
option.desc: If set to true, all droppable positions are calculated on every mousemove. Caution: This solves issues on highly dynamic pages, but dramatically decreases performance.

option.name: revert
option.desc: If set to true, the element will return to its start position when dragging stops. Possible string values: 'valid', 'invalid'. If set to invalid, revert will only occur if the draggable has not been dropped on a droppable. For valid, it's the other way around.

option.name: revertDuration
option.desc: The duration of the revert animation, in milliseconds. Ignored if revert is false.

option.name: scope
option.desc: Used to group sets of draggable and droppable items, in addition to droppable's accept option. A draggable with the same scope value as a droppable will be accepted by the droppable.

option.name: scroll
option.desc: If set to true, container auto-scrolls while dragging.

option.name: scrollSensitivity
option.desc: Distance in pixels from the edge of the viewport after which the viewport should scroll. Distance is relative to pointer, not the draggable.

option.name: scrollSpeed
option.desc: The speed at which the window should scroll once the mouse pointer gets within the scrollSensitivity distance.

option.name: snap
option.desc: If set to a selector or to true (equivalent to '.ui-draggable'), the draggable will snap to the edges of the selected elements when near an edge of the element.

option.name: snapMode
option.desc: Determines which edges of snap elements the draggable will snap to. Ignored if snap is false. Possible values: 'inner', 'outer', 'both'

option.name: snapTolerance
option.desc: The distance in pixels from the snap element edges at which snapping should occur. Ignored if snap is false.

option.name: stack
option.desc: Controls the z-Index of the set of elements that match the selector, always brings to front the dragged item. Very useful in things like window managers.

option.name: zIndex
option.desc: z-index for the helper while being dragged.

event.name: start
event.desc: This event is triggered when dragging starts.

event.name: drag
event.desc: This event is triggered when the mouse is moved during the dragging.

event.name: stop
event.desc: This event is triggered when dragging stops.

example.desc: Initialize a draggable with default options.
